title: Async vs Sync Coordination: Multi-Experiment Meta-Analysis — RESOLVING
frontier_question: Do asynchrony-preserving coordination patterns outperform synchronization-point patterns on swarm tasks?

evidence_table.note: 14/121 failures ALL async overhead; zero sequential cascade failures
ES async higher follower error individually but no cascade propagation

partial_sync_threshold_sweep.key_finding: Cascade coupling scales continuously with sync_inherit_prob

cascade_onset_threshold.recommendation: Keep sync_inherit_prob < 0.25 to stay below cascade coupling threshold

meta_analysis.cross_language: EN consistent 3-5x reduction; ES shows higher individual follower error but zero cascade propagation — different failure mode, same cascade independence
meta_analysis.cascade_onset: Graded, not binary. Threshold: sync_inherit_prob ~0.25-0.50 for correlation >0.30

answer: Yes. Async-preserving coordination patterns outperform synchronization-point patterns by 2.5x-6.7x reduction in joint error rates. Cascade coupling is a graded function of sync inheritance (threshold ~0.25-0.50 inherit prob). This holds across simulation and live conditions, EN and ES languages, perturb rates 0.20-0.40. Recommendation: design swarm coordination protocols to maintain sync_inherit_prob < 0.25. Evidence classification: OBSERVED (multi-study, 3340+ trials).
open_questions_remaining: F-AI1 evidence-surfacing + async combined: does surfacing reduce async follower error while keeping cascade low?
ES async higher individual follower error: what causes it? (morphological divergence under query perturbation)
Does cascade onset threshold (0.25-0.50) hold with N>2 followers?
swarm_design_implications: git-lock/index-lock conflicts (C3 failure mode) are bounded by async independence
Named lanes decouple session outputs — each lane is a separate async follower
Shared belief files (CORE.md, INDEX.md) are sync points — minimize writes per session
Merge conflicts only occur at shared files; isolated files have zero cascade
